revision.text:
[[Image:Nana apache.jpg|thumb|right|Nana]] '''Kas-tziden''' ("Broken Foot") or '''Haškɛnadɨltla''' ("Angry, He is Agitated"), more widely known by his Mexican-Spanish appellation '''Nana''' ("grandma" or "lullaby") (1800? – May 19, 1896), was a [[warrior]] and [[tribal chief|chief]] of the [[Chiricahua#Bands|Chihenne]] band (better known as ''Warm Springs Apache'') of the [[Chiricahua]] [[Apache]]. In the 1850s and 1860s he was one of the best known leaders of the Bedonkohe and Chihenne, along with [[Delgadito (Apache chief)|Tudeevia]] (''Dudeevia'', better known as ''Delgadito'' - "Little Thin", "Skinny"),<ref>[http://www.fortsillapache-nsn.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&id=5&layout=blog&Itemid=7 Fort Sill Apache Tribal Leaders]</ref> [[Cuchillo Negro]], [[Ponce (Apache)|Ponce]] and [[Loco (Apache)|Loco]] ("crazy", "mad"). He was a nephew of Delgadito, and married a sister of [[Geronimo]].
==Description== Captain [[John Gregory Bourke]] described Nana as having "a strong face marked with intelligence, courage and good nature, but with an under stratum of cruelty and vindictiveness".<ref name="Bourke1886">{{cite book|last=Bourke|first=John Gregory|title=An Apache Campaign in the Sierra Madre: An Account of the Expedition in Pursuit of the Hostile Chiricahua Apaches in the Spring of 1883|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2OcNAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA99|year=1886|publisher=C. Scribner's sons|page=99}}</ref> [[Charles Fletcher Lummis]] claimed that Nana wore gold watch chains in each ear lobe, presumably taken from dead victims.<ref name="Hodge1912">{{cite book|last=Hodge|first=Frederick Webb|title=Handbook of American Indians North of Mexico: N-Z|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i9c_AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA19|year=1912|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office|page=19}}</ref><ref name="Lummis1893">{{cite book|last=Lummis|first=Charles Fletcher|title=Land of Poco Tiempo|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Gy5DAAAAIAAJ|year=1893|page=178}}</ref>
== Early Fights == He fought alongside [[Mangas Coloradas]] and his mixed Tchihende-[[Chiricahua#Bands|Bedonkohe]] band until Mangas Coloradas was killed while in the custody of the [[California Column]] in January 1863. In [[Mexico]] he undertook many joint raids with the [[Chiricahua#Bands|Nednhi]] of [[Juh]] and [[Natiza]] against the Mexicans. After Ponce, Cuchillo Negro and Delgadito were killed too, [[Victorio]] took over the Tchihende leadership, joined by the leaderless Bedonkohe (Taklishim, old Mahko's son, had not been able to save his father's leadership in front of his competitors Mano Mocha and Luis). Nana, although at least 20 years older than Victorio, married the latter's elder sister, cementing his position as a leader.<ref name="Hutton2016">{{cite book|last=Hutton|first=Paul Andrew|title=The Apache Wars: The Hunt for Geronimo, the Apache Kid, and the Captive Boy Who Started the Longest War in American History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=td5UCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA290|date=3 May 2016|publisher=Crown/Archetype|isbn=978-0-7704-3582-0|pages=44, 60, 276}}</ref>
== Victorio's War == After several failed attempts to peacefully live on a reservation in their own country, Victorio and Nana gave up trying and fought back against the Americans and Mexicans. The Bedonkohe and Chihenne were joined by more than 80 warriors of the [[Mescalero|Mescalero Apache]] under their old chief Caballero. Victorio and Nana therefore had about 200 warriors.<ref name="Roberts1994">{{cite book|last=Roberts|first=David|title=Once They Moved Like The Wind: Cochise, Geronimo, And The Apache Wars|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VhDJ4Or38I8C|date=19 July 1994|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-0-671-88556-4|pages=190–196}}</ref>
During the [[Apache Wars]] and especially [[Victorio's War]] Nana raided areas of Texas and Mexico with [[Victorio]]. While Nana and a small group was away on a scouting mission, Victorio and his band were surrounded and killed by soldiers of the Mexican Army under Joaquin Terrazas at the [[Battle of Tres Castillos]] in October 1880. 68 women and children were captured by the Mexicans and sold as slaves in Mexico.<ref name="Roberts1994"/>
== Nana's Raids == After Victorio's death, Nana and his followers hid in the Sierra Madre. Several prestigious leaders and warriors, such as [[Fun (Apache)|Fun]] (''Yiy-gholl'', ''Yiy-joll'', ''Yiy-zholl'', also known as ''Larry Fun''), [[Ka-ya-ten-nae]] (''Ka-e-te-nay'', ''Kadhateni'' or ''Kieta'' - "Fights Without Arrows", "Cartridges All Gone") took the leadership of the Tchihende, Bedonkohe, [[Chiricahua#Bands|Tsokanende]] and Nednhi bands beside the already established Apache band leaders Nana, Loco, Mangas, [[Naiche]], Geronimo and Juh.
Nana, now almost 80 years old (according to some reports, nearly 90-years), formed his own war party with the Chihenne (Warm Springs Apache), enlisting loitering warriors in the reservations. His band joined by 15 Tsokanende, 12 Mescalero warriors and a couple of Navajo, plus women and children, began raiding Army supply trains and isolated settlers. In less than a month Nana fought seven or eight battles stretching over the course of 1,000 miles and killed 30-40 Americans, at least as many Mexicans, captured about 200 horses to replace 100 ridden to death and then fled back to Mexico.<ref name="Sweeney2012">{{cite book | author=Sweeney, Edwin R.| title=From Chochise to Geronimo: The Chiricahua Apaches 1874-1886 | location=Norman, OK| publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|year=2012 | ISBN=978-0-8061-4272-2}}</ref>{{rp|174–177}} He and his small force, evaded more than 1,000 soldiers, 300-400 civilian militia volunteers and Apache and Navajo Indian Scouts.<ref>[http://www.dchieftain.com/news/42295-07-03-04.html Nana's Raid — Apaches in Socorro County] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091215120851/http://dchieftain.com/news/42295-07-03-04.html |date=2009-12-15 }}</ref><ref name="Lekson1987">{{cite book|last=Lekson|first=Stephen H.|title=Nana's Raid: Apache Warfare in Southern New Mexico, 1881|year=1987|publisher=Texas Western Press, University of Texas at El Paso|isbn=978-0-87404-159-0}}</ref><ref name="Wellman1987">{{cite book|last=Wellman|first=Paul Iselin|title=Death in the Desert: The Fifty Years' War for the Great Southwest|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P5MM7isgtoUC&pg=PA195|date=January 1987|publisher=U of Nebraska Press|isbn=0-8032-9722-X|pages=195–205|chapter=The Raid of Old Nana}}</ref>
== Nana's Death == Nana survived the Apache Wars. Upon surrender in March 1886 he, other Apache warriors and [[Apache Scouts]] were sent as prisoners of war to Florida and Alabama.<ref name="Watt2012">{{cite book|last=Watt|first=Robert|title=Apache Tactics 1830–86|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3eC6CwAAQBAJ&pg=PA12|date=20 January 2012|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-84908-631-8|pages=11–12}}</ref> In 1894, they were relocated to [[Fort Sill]] in the Indian Territory, present-day Oklahoma. Nana died of natural causes in 1896.<ref name="Thrapp1991">{{cite book|last=Thrapp|first=Dan L.|title=Encyclopedia of Frontier Biography: G-O|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hc35mM0PqSQC&pg=PA1038|date=1 August 1991|publisher=U of Nebraska Press|isbn=0-8032-9419-0|pages=1038–1039}}</ref><ref name="Fredriksen2001">{{cite book|last=Fredriksen|first=John C.|title=America's Military Adversaries: From Colonial Times to the Present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZJlm7AQK-T4C&pg=PA348|year=2001|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-57607-603-3|page=348}}</ref>
== Legacy == Nana has a special reputation among Apache war chiefs. He was still an active warrior well into his eighties. He had tenacity, stamina, courage and an uncanny ability to improvise in a fight to minimize his losses. He showed no mercy in battle, yet could be considerate when dealing with civilians.<ref name="Sweeney2012" />{{rp|174–175}} When Nana was executing guerrilla tactics in the 1880's, he was half blind, crooked from arthritis, but once he sat in the saddle, he rode "like the devil." <ref name="Roberts1994"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== *''Nana's Raid: Apache Warfare in Southern New Mexico, 1881'' (Lekson, 1987)
==External links== *[http://azmemory.lib.az.us/cdm4/item_viewer.php?CISOROOT=/shmamerind&CISOPTR=89&REC=16 Nana, Apache Chief] at the Arizona Memory Project *[https://books.google.com/books?id=hc35mM0PqSQC&pg=PA1038 Nana (Kas-tziden)] from the ''Encyclopedia of Frontier Biography'', via [[Google Books]] *[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hawp:@FIELD(SUBJ+@band(+Nana,++Apache+Chief,++ca++1806+1896++)) Nana in photograph of the Council between General Crook and Geronimo] from the U.S. government's ''American Memory'' website *[http://www.historynet.com/culture/native_american_history/4429252.html?featured=y&c=y Warm Springs Apache Leader Nana: The 80-Year-Old Warrior Turned the Tables] at the Weider History Group's historynet.com
{{DEFAULTSORT:Nana}} [[Category:1896 deaths]] [[Category:Chiricahua]] [[Category:Native American leaders]] [[Category:Year of birth uncertain]] [[Category:Apache people]] [[Category:Native Americans imprisoned at Fort Marion]]

[[File:Natalie Batalha.jpg|thumb|Natalie Batalha]] '''Natalie Batalha''' is a research astronomer in the Space Sciences Division of [[NASA Ames Research Center]]. She holds the position of Co-Investigator and Kepler Mission Scientist on the [[Kepler Mission]], the first mission capable of finding Earth-size planets around other stars.<ref name="NASA-bio"/><ref name="AMES-bio"/><ref name="Kepler-bio"/>
==Biography== Batalha began her career as a [[Astronomical spectroscopy|stellar spectroscopist]], studying sun-like stars. She holds a bachelor's degree in physics from the [[University of California, Berkeley]], a doctorate in astrophysics from [[UC Santa Cruz]], and completed a post-doctoral fellowship in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.<ref name="AMES-bio"/>
==Career==
In 1997, [[William Borucki]] added Batalha to the science team and she started work on transit photometry. She has been involved with the Kepler Mission since the design and funding, and as one of the original Co-Investigators was responsible for the selection of the more than 150,000 stars monitored by the telescope. She now works closely with team members at Ames Research Center to identify viable planets from the data of the Kepler mission. She led the analysis that yielded the discovery in 2011 of [[Kepler 10b]], the first confirmed rocky planet outside our solar system.<ref name="Lemonick-2012"/>
In 2017, Batalha and two other exoplanet scientists were named to Time Magazine's 100 Most Influential People in the World.<ref name="Stern-2017"/>
In 2017, Batalha won Smithsonian Magazine's American Ingenuity Award in Physical Sciences.<ref name="Ingenuity Awards">{{cite web |title=2017 American Ingenuity Award Winners |url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/ingenuity/ceremonies/2017-winners/ |website=Smithsonian Magazine |publisher=Smithsonian |accessdate=11 October 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist |refs= <ref name="NASA-bio">{{cite web |title=Mission Scientist: Natalie Batalha |publisher=[[NASA]] |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/kepler/team/batalha.html#.Upv5RsQW0hs |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150915000257/http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/kepler/team/batalha.html#.VnrAsnbYRpg |archivedate=September 15, 2015}}</ref>
<ref name="AMES-bio">{{cite web |title=Natalie Batalha |work=Space Science and Astrobiology at Ames |publisher=NASA |url=http://spacescience.arc.nasa.gov/staff/natalie-batalha |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923015735/http://spacescience.arc.nasa.gov/staff/natalie-batalha |archivedate=September 23, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
<ref name="Kepler-bio">{{cite web |title=Natalie Batalha |work=Kepler |publisher=NASA: Ames Research Center |url=http://kepler.nasa.gov/Mission/team/coi/natalieBatalha/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150921220420/http://kepler.nasa.gov/Mission/team/coi/natalieBatalha/ |archivedate=September 21, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
<ref name="Lemonick-2012">{{cite book |last=Lemonick |first=Michael D |year=2012 |title=Mirror Earth : the search for our planet's twin |location=New York |publisher=Walker |isbn=978-0-8027-7900-7}}</ref>
<ref name="Stern-2017">{{Cite magazine |last=Stern |first=Alan |title=Natalie Batalha, Guillem Anglada-Escudé and Michaël Gillon |department=The World’s 100 Most Influential People |work=Time |url=http://time.com/collection/2017-time-100/4742707/natalie-batalha-guillem-anglada-escude-michael-gillon/ |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170502205017/http://time.com/collection/2017-time-100/4742707/natalie-batalha-guillem-anglada-escude-michael-gillon/ |archivedate=2 May 2017}}</ref> }}
{{Authority control}}

[[File:Nellie Fassett Crosby.jpg|thumb|289px|Nellie Fassett Crosby in 1913.]] '''Nellie Fassett''' (Mrs. John Sherwin Crosby) was an American [[feminist]], political organizer, and [[suffragette]] during the 1890s through 1920s in [[New York City]].<ref name=politicalwomen>{{cite web |author=[[Jo Freeman]] |url=http://uic.edu/orgs/cwluherstory/jofreeman/polhistory/1912.htm |title=The Rise of Political Woman in the Election of 1912 |accessdate=2009-07-25 |quote=One of those attending the breakfast was Nellie Fassett (Mrs. John Sherwin) Crosby of New York City. She was not a political wife, but a political organizer and the personal friend of William Jennings Bryan. Mrs. Crosby had been organizing and presiding over women's political clubs since the 1890s. She had founded the Woman's Democratic Club of New York City in 1905 — "the only organization of Democratic women [in New York] to outlive its birth year" — and was still its only president |publisher=[[University of Illinois]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511132006/http://www.uic.edu/orgs/cwluherstory/jofreeman/polhistory/1912.htm |archivedate=2009-05-11 |df= }}</ref>
She was married to [[John Sherwin Crosby]].<ref name=politicalwomen/> Her personal friends included [[William Jennings Bryan]].<ref name=politicalwomen/>
==Politics== Fassett was the founder, in 1905, and first president of the Women's Democratic Club of New York City.<ref name=politicalwomen/> It was the first permanent national political organization exclusively established by and for women.
[[File:Nellie Fassett and Elisabeth Marbury.jpg|thumb|280px|Nellie Fassett (left) with [[Elisabeth Marbury]] (circa 1913).]] The pioneering American theatrical and literary agent [[Elisabeth Marbury]] was a member, and also involved in Democratic politics and [[Georgism]].
In 1913 she gave a victory breakfast at the [[Waldorf-Astoria]] for the new First Lady [[Ellen Axson Wilson]] and her children.<ref name=politicalwomen/>
In 1918 Fassett was named as the representative of New York State on the Woman's Advisory Committee of the [[Democratic National Committee]].<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Democrats Choose Mrs. J.S. Crosby. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1918/02/28/109328886.pdf |quote=Mrs. John Sherwin Crosby of New York City has been named as the representative of New York State on the Woman's Advisory Committee of the Democratic ... |work=[[New York Times]] |date=February 28, 1918 |accessdate=2009-07-25 | format=PDF}}</ref>
==See also== * {{C|American suffragists}}
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fassett, Nellie}} [[Category:American women's rights activists]] [[Category:American feminists]] [[Category:American suffragists]] [[Category:Activists from New York (state)]] [[Category:Georgists]] [[Category:People from Manhattan]] [[Category:New York (state) Democrats]] [[Category:1900s in New York (state)]] [[Category:1910s in New York (state)]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:Year of death missing]]

revision.text:
'''Otto Hornung''' (1920<ref name=fip>http://hps.gr/fipliterature/bureau/hornung.html FIP Literature Commission profile retrieved 30 September 2009.</ref> in [[Ostrava]]<ref name=gsm>"The Slania I Knew" by Otto Hornung in ''Gibbons Stamp Monthly'', June 2005, p.90.</ref> – 8 January 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.briefmarken.de/news/490-farewell-otto-hornung |title=Farewell Otto Hornung |publisher=briefmarken.de |date= |accessdate=2013-02-01}}</ref>) was a distinguished [[philatelist]] and philatelic journalist who won Gold medals at several [[philatelic exhibition]]s and was a Fellow of The [[Royal Philatelic Society London]]. He signed the [[Roll of Distinguished Philatelists]] in 1993 and lived in Wembley, London.
== Early life == Whilst in Ostrava, Hornung witnessed the German invasion of Czechoslovakia in March 1939 but managed to escape to [[Bohumín|Bogumin]], then in unoccupied Poland, dressed as a postman in the mail wagon of a goods train.<ref name=gsm/> After that he joined the Czechoslovak Legion. Hornung spoke Polish and Czech fluently as both were used freely in Ostrava.
== Philatelic career == Hornung was a former Secretary of the [[Philatelic Traders Society]] and organiser of the [[Stampex]] show.<ref name=fip/> He was also a founder member of the ''Association Internationale des Journalistes Philateliques'' (AIJP) in 1952 and its former President.<ref name=fip/> As a philatelist, Hornung specialised in the stamps and [[postal history]] of Turkey and won Large Gold medals at India 1989, New Zealand 1990, London 1990, Philatokyo 1991 and Granada 1992.<ref name=fip/>
== Philatelic memberships == Hornung was a member of the following societies (amongst others): *Czechoslovak Philatelic Society of Great Britain *The [[Oriental Philatelic Association of London]] *International Association of Philatelic Journalists *Royal Philatelic Society London
== Philatelic publications == *''The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Stamp Collecting'', Hamlyn, London, 1970. {{ISBN|0-600-01797-4}} *''Wie Sammle Ich Richtig Briefmarken'', Verlag Werner Dausien, 1972. {{ISBN|3-7684-4233-0}} (German language) *''The Czecho-Slovak Legion in Poland and Russia 1939-1945 and Czechoslovaks in the Middle East, 1940 - 1943'', [[Czechoslovak Philatelic Society of Great Britain]], 2003. (With Dr. Vratislav Palkoska) *''The Early Postal History of Carpatho-Ukraine with Particular Reference to The Usage Of The First Postage Stamps of Austria'', 2007. {{ISBN|978-0-9536555-9-5}}
== References == <references/>
== External links == *[http://hps.gr/fipliterature/bureau/hornung.jpg Photograph of Otto Hornung.] *[http://www.japhila.cz/hof/0034/index0034a.htm Virtual exhibit on Carpatho-Ukraine at Exponet.]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hornung, Otto}} [[Category:People from Ostrava]] [[Category:Philatelists]] [[Category:1920 births]] [[Category:Czech emigrants to the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Philatelic Society London]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:Signatories to the Roll of Distinguished Philatelists]] [[Category:Czechoslovak emigrants to the United Kingdom]]
{{philatelist-stub}}

{{about|the English paranormalist|the Chief Justice of Tasmania|Peter Underwood (judge)}}
[[File:Peter_Underwood,_parapsychologist,_paranormal_historian,_ghost_hunter.jpg|thumb|right|Peter Underwood]]
'''Peter Underwood''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|FRSA}} (16 May 1923 – 26 November 2014) was an English [[author]], [[Television presenter|broadcaster]] and [[Parapsychology|parapsychologist]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Williams|first1=Michael|title=Peter Underwood obituary|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/dec/17/peter-underwood|website=The Guardian|accessdate=2 December 2015}}.</ref> Underwood was born in [[Letchworth]], [[Hertfordshire]]. Described as "an indefatigable [[ghost hunting|ghost hunter]]", he wrote many books which surveyed alleged [[haunting]]s within the United Kingdom - beginning the trend of comprehensive regional 'guides' to (purportedly) haunted places. One of his well-known investigations concerned [[Borley Rectory]], which he also wrote about.<ref>{{cite web|title=Peter Underwood - obituary|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/11310318/Peter-Underwood-obituary.html|website=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=2 December 2015}}.</ref>
==Early life== Born into a family who were [[Plymouth Brethren]], Underwood had his first paranormal experience at the age of nine, when he claimed to have seen an apparition of his father, who had died earlier the same day, standing at the bottom of his bed.<ref>{{Cite book|title = No Common Task|last = Underwood|first = Peter|publisher = Harrap|year = 1983|isbn = 024553959X|location = London|pages = 18–19}}</ref> During his childhood, his maternal grandparents lived for a time at Rosehall, a seventeenth century Hertfordshire house which it was claimed was haunted, supposedly having a bedroom in which guests claimed to have seen the figure of a headless man. Underwood's interest in hauntings and psychic matters began to take root at that time.<ref>Profile of Peter Underwood: {{cite web|last1=Adams|first1=Paul|title=Harry Price Website|url=http://www.harrypricewebsite.co.uk/Profiles/peterunderwood.htm|accessdate=2 December 2015}}; see also the first chapter of {{Cite book|title = No Common Task|last = Underwood|first = Peter|publisher = Harrap|year = 1983|isbn = 024553959X|location = London|pages = 13–39}}</ref>
At the beginning of the [[Second World War]], Underwood joined the publishing firm of [[J.M. Dent & Sons]] in [[Letchworth Garden City]]. In January 1942 he was called up for active service with the [[Suffolk Regiment]]. After collapsing at a rifle range at [[Bury St Edmunds]], Underwood was diagnosed with a serious chest ailment which rendered him unfit for active service. He was discharged from the army and returned to Dents. On 15 July 1944 Underwood married his wife Joyce at [[Church of St. Mary the Virgin, Baldock|St. Mary's Church]] in nearby [[Baldock]] (she died in 2003 after having suffered with [[Parkinson's Disease]] for 14 years).<ref>{{Cite book|title = No Common Task|last = Underwood|first = Peter|publisher = Harrap|year = 1983|isbn = 024553959X|location = London|page = 39}}</ref>
Underwood was much influenced by the work of [[Harry Price]] - the grandfather of ghost-hunting - and was particularly struck by Price's ‘The End of Borley Rectory’, which he read immediately when it was first published in 1946.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/No-Common-Task-Autobiography-Hunter/dp/024553959X/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1476118912&sr=1-2&keywords=no+common+task|title=No Common Task: Autobiography of a Ghost Hunter|last=Underwood|first=Peter|date=1983|publisher=George G.Harrap & Co Ltd|year=|isbn=9780245539596|edition=1st|location=London|pages=45|language=English|via=}}</ref> Investigating Borley himself, he corresponded with Price about it. Price then invited Underwood to join the Ghost Club , of which he would later become President.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Borley-Rectory-Companion-Paul-Adams/dp/0750950676/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1476119098&sr=1-1&keywords=borley+rectory+companion|title=The Borley Rectory Companion|last=Adams|first=Paul|last2=Underwood|first2=Peter|last3=Brazil|first3=Eddie|date=2009|publisher=The History Press|year=|isbn=9780750950671|edition=1st|location=Stroud|pages=300|language=English|via=}}</ref>
==Investigating the Paranormal== During his investigations into the [[Borley Rectory]] case, over a period of years, Underwood traced and personally interviewed almost every living person who had been connected with what the press had dubbed the 'most haunted house in England'. He built up a volume of correspondence with paranormal investigator [[Harry Price]] and after Price's death, [[Paul Tabori]] would become literary executor of the Harry Price Estate, with whom Underwood worked with to publish all his research into Borley. (Price had written published two books about Borley- ''The Most Haunted House in England'' (1940), and ''The End of Borley Rectory'' (1946), from which Underwood 'compile[d] a really comprehensive index of the combined volumes'.)<ref>{{Cite book|title = No Common Task|last = Underwood|first = Peter|publisher = Harrap|year = 1983|isbn = 024553959X|location = London|pages = 187; 70–71}}; {{cite book|last1=Price|first1=Harry|title=The Most Haunted House in England: Ten Years Investigation of Borley Rectory|date=1940|publisher=Longman's Green}}; {{cite book|last1=Price|first1=Harry|title=The End of Borley Rectory - The Most Haunted House in England|date=1946|publisher=Harrap}}</ref>
Underwood's published work changed the field of literature on the paranormal. For example, his much imitated ''Gazetteer of British Ghosts'' (1971)<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,909941,00.html|title=Modern Living: The Great Ghost Haunts|date=1971-08-30|newspaper=Time|issn=0040-781X|access-date=2016-11-10}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Karpeles|first=Maud|last2=Smith|first2=A. W.|last3=Gunda|first3=Béla|last4=Hudspeth|first4=W. H.|last5=Briggs|first5=K. M.|last6=Ettlinger|first6=Ellen|last7=Briggs|first7=Katharine M.|last8=Brown|first8=Theo|last9=Burland|first9=C. A.|date=1971-09-01|title=Book Reviews|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/0015587X.1971.9716735|journal=Folklore|volume=82|issue=3|pages=249–260|doi=10.1080/0015587X.1971.9716735|issn=0015-587X}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.com/maps/d/viewer?mid=1l2oSivAxg0glU1htRW2sjj611D8&usp=sharing|title=The A-Z of British Ghosts|website=www.google.com|access-date=2016-11-10}}</ref> and ''[[Haunted London (Underwood book)|Haunted London]]'' (1973) - previously unheard of comprehensive and well-researched surveys (or geographical dictionaries - [[gazetteers]]) - which, through their encyclopaedic thoroughness, imparted authority to Underwood as an author on the subject he devoted his life to - [[ghost hunting]]. They also encouraged others to use them as resources to use to visit the sites he investigated for themselves. Underwood came to be known as a 'veteran psychical researcher ... representing the middle-ground between scepticism and uncritical belief'; the 'Sherlock Holmes of psychical research' - as [[Dame Jean Conan Doyle]] would say (when introducing him).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Drury|first1=Nevill|title=The Dictionary of the Esoteric|date=2003|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass|isbn=8120819896|page=315}}; {{cite book|last1=Williams|first1=Michael|title=Haunted North Cornwall|date=2014|publisher=The History Press|isbn=0750954396|page=41}}</ref><ref>Peter Underwood; "My Friend Dame Jean Conan Doyle"; pp.128-131; The Shoso-in Bulletin of Japan, Volume 12, 2002, Edited by Hirayama Yuichi & Mel Hughes (Sherlock Holmes Journal) http://shoso.ninja-web.net/Shoso-inBulletin/vol.12.html</ref>
In their book ''Ghosts of Borley'' (1973), Underwood and [[Paul Tabori]] wrote that they believed "some of the phenomena were genuine" at the [[Borley Rectory]].<ref name="Hall 1985">[[Trevor H. Hall|Hall, Trevor H]]. (1985). ''A Note on Borley Rectory: The Most Haunted House in England''. In [[Paul Kurtz]]. ''A Skeptic's Handbook of Parapsychology''. Prometheus Books. pp. 327-338. {{ISBN|0-87975-300-5}}</ref> The researcher [[Trevor H. Hall]] criticized Tabori and Underwood for [[Cherry picking (fallacy)|selective reporting]]. According to Hall, the alleged paranormal phenomena from the rectory were the result of natural causes, such as noises produced by [[rat]]s or flying bats, pranks by local village boys throwing stones at the house, or [[tramp]]s trying to keep warm by lighting small [[fire]]s in the rectory.<ref name="Hall 1985"/>
In his book ''No Common Task: The Autobiography of a Ghost-Hunter'' (1983), Underwood came to the conclusion after years of investigation that 98% of the reports of ghosts and hauntings are likely to have naturalistic explanations such as misidentification, [[hallucination]] or pranks and he was most interested in the 2% of the phenomena that he believed may be genuine.<ref>{{Cite book|title = No Common Task|last = Underwood|first = Peter|publisher = Harrap|year = 1983|isbn = 024553959X|location = London|page = 11}}</ref>
Underwood was a long-standing member of the [[Society for Psychical Research]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gothicpress.freeserve.co.uk/Underwood.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061019124215/http://www.gothicpress.freeserve.co.uk/Underwood.htm |archivedate=2006-10-19 |df= }} Underwood on the Gothic Press website</ref> For some years Underwood was the Honorary Librarian of the [[Constitutional Club]] and the [[Savage Club]], where he was a former Member of the Qualifications Committee. In 1976 a bust of Underwood was sculpted by Patricia Finch, winner of the Gold Medal for Sculpture in [[Venice]] (it currently resides with the Savage Club).
In 2018, a website was published dedicated to chronicling his life and work.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.peterunderwood.org|title=The Life & Work of the Renowned British Ghost-hunter|last=|first=|date=|website=www.peterunderwood.org|language=Default|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-26}}</ref>
==Ghost Club Society==
Having been invited to join [[the Ghost Club]] by [[Harry Price]], Underwood was its President from 1960 to 1993.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Borley Rectory Companion: The Complete Guide to the Most Haunted House in England|last=Adams|first=Paul|last2=Underwood|first2=Peter|last3=Brazil|first3=Eddie|date=2009-04-09|publisher=The History Press|year=|isbn=9780750950671|edition=1st|location=Stroud|pages=301|language=English|quote=|via=}}</ref> In 1994, Underwood formed the Ghost Club Society which was formed after his departure from the Ghost Club.<ref name="book1">{{Cite book | last = Cheung | first = Theresa | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = The Element Encyclopedia of the Psychic World | publisher = Harper Element | series = | volume = | edition = | date = 2006 | location = | pages = 244 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-00-721148-7 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}</ref> Membership to the Ghost Club Society was by invitation only. It was reported that the group had several hundred members.<ref name="book1"/><ref>{{cite news | last = Darnton| first = John| coauthors = | title = Was it a ghost of a chance - or vice versa?| work = | pages = | publisher = The Houston Chronicle| date = April 30, 1994}}</ref> Quarterly newsletters were published to members and regular meetings held around the United Kingdom.<ref name="book1"/>
==Recognition==
In recognition of his more than seventy years of paranormal investigations - [[Jean Conan Doyle|Dame Jean Conan Doyle]] described him as 'The Sherlock Holmes of Psychical Research' <ref name=sherlockpsychic>{{cite book|last1=Williams|first1=Michael|title=Haunted North Cornwall|date=2014|publisher=The History Press|isbn=0750954396|page=41}}; {{cite web|last1=Williams|first1=Michael|title=Peter Underwood obituary|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/dec/17/peter-underwood|website=The Guardian|accessdate=30 November 2015}}</ref> - Underwood accepted the invitation to be the Patron of The Ghost Research Foundation (founded in [[Oxford]] in 1992), which termed him the ''King of Ghost Hunters''. In 2000 Underwood was contacted by Clark R. Schmidt, Doctor of Esoteric Sciences from Celestial Visions School of Metaphysical Arts in Fort Lauderdale (founded in 1994) Florida, to become a lifelong member of the Universal Parapsychological and Metaphysical Association (founded in 1996) - which he accepted and shortly before his death he accepted an invitation to be the Patron of [[Paranormal Site Investigators]] (UK).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hidden-highgate.org/peter-underwood-r-p-1923-2014/|title=Peter Underwood R.I.P 1923 – 2014|publisher=hidden-highgate.org/|date=29 November 2014}}</ref>
==Bibliography== *''Gazetteer of British Ghosts'' (1971) *''Gazetteer of Scottish & Irish Ghosts'' (1973) *''Into the Occult'' (1972) *''A Host of Hauntings'' (1973) *''[[Haunted London (Underwood book)|Haunted London]]'' (1973) *''Ghosts of Borley'' (1973) *''Deeper into the Occult'' (1975) *''The Vampire's Bedside Companion: The Amazing World of Vampires in Fact and Fiction'' (1975) *''Lives to Remember'' (1975) *''Dictionary of the Supernatural'' (1978) *''Dictionary of Occult and the Supernatural'' (1979) *''Ghosts of North-West England'' (1978) *''Ghosts of Wales'' (1978) *''Hauntings: New Light on Famous Cases'' (1977) *''A Ghost Hunters Handbook'' (1980) *''Complete Book of Dowsing & Divining'' (1980) *''Ghosts of Devon'' (1982) *''Ghosts of Cornwall'' (1983) *''Ghosts of Somerset'' (1999) *''Ghosts of Hampshire'' ''& The Isle of Wight'' (1982) *''Ghosts of Kent'' (1984) *''This Haunted Isle'' (1984) *''The Ghost Hunters: Who they are and what they do'' (1985) *''Queen Victoria's Other World'' (1986) *''The Ghost Hunter's Guide'' (1986) *''West Country Hauntings'' (1988) *''Mysterious Places'' (1988) *''Ghosts of Dorset'' (1988) *''Jack the Ripper - 100 years of mystery'' (1987) *''Horror Man - Boris Karloff'' (1972) *''Life's a Drag: Danny La Rue'' (1974) *''No Common Task: Autobiography of a Ghost Hunter'' (1983) *''Thirteen Famous Ghost Stories'' (1977) *''Ghosts of Wiltshire'' (1989) *''Ghostly Encounters'' (1992) *''Ghosts & Phantoms of the West'' (1993) *''Exorcism!'' (1990) *''A-Z of British Ghosts'' (1992) *''Death in Hollywood'' (1992) *''Ghosts & How to See Them'' (1993) *''Nights in Haunted Houses'' (1994) *''The Ghost Hunter's Almanac'' (1993) *''Guide to Ghosts and Haunted Places'' (1996) *''Ghosts of North Devon'' (1999) *''Favourite Tales of the Fantastical'' (2000) *''Borley Postscript'' (2001) *''The Murder Club'' (2004) *''The Borley Rectory Companion'' (2008) *''Haunted Gardens'' (2009) *''The Ghost Club - A History'' (2010) *''Shadows in the Nave'' (2011) *''Irish Ghosts'' (2012) *''Where the Ghosts Walk'' (2013) *''Haunted Farnham'' (2013) *''Ghost Hunting with Peter Underwood'' (2014)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *The Life & Times of the Renowned British Ghost-hunter: [http://www.peterunderwood.org peterunderwood.org] *[https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/237156.Peter_Underwood?from_search=true&search_version=service Goodreads Author Profile Page] *[http://www.harrypricewebsite.co.uk/introduction.htm "Harry Price - An Introduction", by Peter Underwood] *[http://www.casebook.org/authors/interviews/int-pu.html "Jack the Ripper and Me", by Peter Underwood] *[https://www.google.com/maps/d/viewer?mid=1l2oSivAxg0glU1htRW2sjj611D8&usp=sharing Google map] of all the locations from ''The Gazetteer of British Ghosts''/''The A-Z of British Ghosts''

{{Other uses|Sarat Chandra (disambiguation){{!}}Sarat Chandra}} {{Infobox person | image = Sarat Chandra Bose.jpg | name = Sarat Chandra Bose | native_name = শরৎচন্দ্র বসু | native_name_lang = bn | alt = | caption = Sarat Chandra Bose | birth_date = {{birth date|1889|09|06}} | birth_name = | birth_place = [[Howrah]], [[Bengal presidency]], [[British India]] | death_date = {{death date|1950|02|20}} | death_place = [[Kolkata]], [[West Bengal]] | nationality = [[India|Indian]] | notable_works = | occupation = [[Politician]] | other_names = |spouse = Bivabati Devi |father = [[Janakinath Bose]] |mother = [[Prabhabati Bose (Dutt)|Prabhavati Dutt]] |education = [[Presidency College, Calcutta|Presidency College]] |alma_mater = {{ubl|[[University of Calcutta]]}} | known_for = [[Politician]], [[Freedom fighters of India|Indian independence activist]] }} {{EngvarB|date=January 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}}
'''Sarat Chandra Bose''' ([[Bengali language|Bengali]]: শরৎ চন্দ্র বসু; 6 September 1889 – 20 February 1950) was a barrister and [[Freedom fighters of India|Indian independence activist]]. He was the son of [[Janakinath Bose]] and elder brother of [[Subhas Chandra Bose]].
==Early life== He was born to [[Janakinath Bose]] (father) and [[Prabhabati Bose (Dutt)|Prabhabati Devi]] in [[Howrah]] on 6 September 1889. [[Prabhabati Bose (Dutt)|Prabhabati Devi]] was part of the famous Dutt family of Hatkhola in north Kolkata. She gave birth to fourteen children, six daughters and eight sons, among whom were nationalist leader Sarat Chandra Bose, [[Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose]] and distinguished cardiologist [[Dr. Sunil Chandra Bose]].
Sarat Bose studied in [[Presidency College, Calcutta|Presidency College]], then affiliated with the [[University of Calcutta]], and then went to England in 1911 to become a barrister. He was called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn. He began a successful legal practice upon his return to India, but later abandoned it to join the [[Indian independence movement]].<ref>.winentrance.com/general_knowledge/arat-chandra-bose.html</ref>
==Political career== In 1936, Bose became the president of the Bengal Pradesh Congress Committee, and served as a member of the [[All India Congress Committee]] from 1936 to 1947. From 1946 to 1947, Bose would lead the Congress delegation to the [[Central Legislative Assembly]]. He strongly supported the formation of the [[Indian National Army]] by Subhas Bose, and actively participated in the [[Quit India movement]]. Following his brother's reported death in 1945, Bose would lead efforts to provide relief and aid to the families of INA soldiers through the [[INA Defence and Relief Committee]]. In 1946, he was appointed Member of the Interim Government for Works, Mines and Powers – the position of a minister in a national executive council led by [[Jawaharlal Nehru]] and [[Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel]], and presided over by the Viceroy of India.
==Bengal partition and later life== However, Bose resigned from the AICC in disagreement over the [[1946 Cabinet Mission to India|Cabinet Mission Plan]]'s call to partition [[Bengal]] between [[West Bengal|Hindu-majority]] and [[East Bengal|Muslim-majority]] regions. He attempt to construct a bid for a [[United Bengal|united but independent Bengal]] and [[North East India|North-East]] with [[Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy]], the Bengali [[All-India Muslim League|Muslim League]] leader. [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]] (President of the [[All-India Muslim League|Muslim League]] who would become Pakistan's founding father) supported it and so did [[Mahatma Gandhi]]. The [[Indian National Congress]] and the Hindu members of Indian Legislative Council from Bengal opposed it. (History of Bengal by R. C. Mazumder) <ref>{{cite book|last1=Christophe Jaffrelot|title=A History of Pakistan and Its Origins|date=2004|publisher=Anthem Press|isbn=9781843311492|page=42|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q9sI_Y2CKAcC&pg=PA42|ref=scb1}}</ref><ref name=scb2>{{cite web|title=Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy : His Life|url=http://thedailynewnation.com/news/34685/huseyn-shaheed-suhrawardy--his-life.html|website=thedailynewnation.com|accessdate=11 January 2015}}</ref> After India's independence, Bose would lead his brother's [[All India Forward Bloc|Forward Bloc]] and form the [[Socialist Republican Party (India)|Socialist Republican Party]], advocating a socialist system for Bengal and India. He died in 1950, in Calcutta.
==Family== {{unreferenced section|date=November 2013}} Sarat Bose married Bivabati Devi in 1910 and the couple had eight children. Their children included Dr. Asoke Nath Bose,<ref>How Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose escaped Kolkata this day 1941, http://www.makingindia.co/online-news-english/2017/01/17/history-netaji-subhash-chandra-bose-escaped-kolkata-this-day-1941/</ref> a Doctorate in Chemistry from Germany and eminent engineer, Amiya Nath Bose who participated in the Quit India Movement, became a Member Parliament and was also the Indian ambassador to Burma, Sisir Kumar Bose,<ref>Sisir Kumar Bose, ''Sarat Chandra Bose: Remembering My Father'', Netaji Research Bureau, Kolkata, 2014. {{ISBN|978-93-83098-50-7}}</ref> who became a pediatrician and Member of Legislative Assembly, and [[Subrata Bose]], who was an electrical engineer and also a Member of Parliament. His youngest daughter Prof. Chitra Ghosh is a distinguished academician and a social scientist and also a member of the parliament. His grandson, Sumantra Bose, is a professor of comparative politics at the London School of Economics and Political Science.<ref>http://www.lse.ac.uk/government/whosWho/Academic%20profiles/sbose@lseacuk/Home.aspx</ref> [[File:Statue of Sharat Bose.jpg|thumb|Statue of Sharat Chandra Bose in Kolkata]]
==Honors== In January 2014, Sarat Chandra Bose Memorial Lecture was instituted and the maiden lecture was delivered by international historian [[Leonard A. Gordon]], who has penned a joint biography of Sarat and his younger brother [[Subhas Chandra Bose|Subhas]], titled ''Brothers Against The Raj''.<ref>{{cite web|title=History failed to recognize Sarat Chandra Bose: Leonard Gordon|url=http://news.biharprabha.com/2014/01/history-failed-to-recognize-sarat-chandra-bose-leonard-gordon/|work=IANS|publisher=Biharprabha News|accessdate=23 January 2014}}</ref> A statue of Sarat Chandra Bose is situated beside Calcutta High Court.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Sarat Chandra Bose}} *[http://www.indianpost.com/viewstamp.php/Issue%20Date/year/1988/month/9/SARAT%20CHANDRA%20BOSE?PHPSESSID=b5bd4fb0fbea197362b02cdf738d95b6 Bose stamp] * [http://www.getinfy.com/biography/sarat-chandra-bose]

revision.text:
{{Infobox basketball biography | name = Semaj Booker | image = | caption = | position = [[Shooting guard]] / [[Small forward]] | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 5 | weight_lb = 181 | league = [[Junior Basketball Association|JBA]] | team = Seattle Ballers | number = 1 | nationality = American | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1997|6|25}} | birth_place = [[Lakewood, Washington]] | high_school = *[[Lincoln High School (Tacoma, Washington)|Lincoln]] ([[Tacoma, Washington]]) *[[Curtis Senior High School|Curtis]] ([[University Place, Washington]]) *[[Clover Park High School|Clover Park]] (Lakewood, Washington) | draft_year = | draft_round = | draft_pick = | draft_team = | career_start = 2018 | years1 = 2018–present | team1 = [[Seattle Ballers]] | highlights = }}
'''Semaj Booker''' (born June 25, 1997) is an American professional [[basketball]] player and former [[Runaway (dependent)|runaway]] child from [[Lakewood, Washington]]. He gained national attention in 2007, at age nine, for escaping from his home in Lakewood to [[San Antonio|San Antonio, Texas]] on his own, traveling by [[car]] as a driver and by [[airplane]] as a passenger. Booker grew up to become a standout high school basketball player, attending four different schools, including [[Curtis Senior High School]] and [[Clover Park High School]]. He currently plays for the [[Seattle Ballers]] of the [[Junior Basketball Association]] (JBA).
== Early life and runaway attempts == Booker was born to Sakinah Booker, a [[single parent|single mother]], and had three brothers, including Demarius, and a younger sister.<ref name="hated">{{cite web |last1=Clarridge |first1=Christine |title=9-year-old caught flights back to Texas because "he hated it here" |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/9-year-old-caught-flights-back-to-texas-because-he-hated-it-here/ |website=[[The Seattle Times]] |accessdate=June 15, 2018 |date=January 18, 2007}}</ref><ref name="seattletimes">{{cite web |last1=Jenks |first1=Jayson |title=Semaj Booker made national headlines at age 9 for running away. He hasn't stopped running since. |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/sports/high-school/semaj-booker-made-headlines-at-age-9-for-running-away-his-life-since-then-reveals-a-familiar-pattern-2/ |website=[[The Seattle Times]] |accessdate=June 15, 2018 |date=June 30, 2017}}</ref> According to his mother, he regularly attempted to escape his mother's apartment in [[Lakewood, Washington]] to be with a [[father figure]] in his grandfather, who lived in [[Dallas|Dallas, Texas]].<ref name="cbs">{{cite web |last1=Conroy |first1=Scott |title=Mom: Runaway Jetsetting Son Needs A Dad |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/mom-runaway-jetsetting-son-needs-a-dad/ |publisher=[[CBS News]] |accessdate=June 15, 2018 |date=January 18, 2007}}</ref> Booker's mother also claimed that he "hated" his neighborhood.<ref name=hated/>
On January 14, 2008, he stole a 1986 [[Acura]] car from a neighbor, driving it up to 90 miles per hour (145 km/h)— having learned the skill through video games— before crashing during a [[Car chase|police chase]].<ref name="wapo">{{cite web |last1=Harden |first1=Blaine |title=A Runaway Situation in Seattle |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/18/AR2007011801681.html?noredirect=on |website=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=June 15, 2018 |date=January 19, 2007}}</ref> In the following morning, after being excused from [[Youth detention center|juvenile detention]], Booker traveled to [[Seattle–Tacoma International Airport]] on a [[bus]], without his mother's knowledge.<ref name=seattletimes/><ref name=wapo/> He received a boarding pass from [[Southwest Airlines]] for a flight to [[San Antonio|San Antonio, Texas]] via [[Phoenix, Arizona]], after lying that he was a 12-year-old with the last name "Williams" and that his mother was already in the boarding area.<ref name="cnn">{{cite web |last1=Simon |first1=Dan |title=9-year-old runaway snuck on two flights |url=http://www.cnn.com/CNN/Programs/anderson.cooper.360/blog/2007/01/9-year-old-runaway-snuck-on-two.html |publisher=[[CNN]] |accessdate=June 15, 2018 |date=January 19, 2007}}</ref><ref name=pi>{{cite web |last1=Mitchell |first1=Melanthia |title=9-year-old's cunning impresses many |url=https://www.postindependent.com/news/9-year-olds-cunning-impresses-many/ |website=Post Independent |accessdate=June 15, 2018 |date=January 19, 2007}}</ref> However, in San Antonio, he was stopped after attempting to board another flight to Dallas.<ref name=pi/>
The incident gained the attention of [[Norm Dicks]], the local [[United States House of Representatives|U. S. Representative]], who said, "If a 9-year-old can exploit this (air travel) security system, we are going to have to look into the procedures."<ref name=wapo/> ''[[The Washington Post]]'' labeled Booker possibly "the most persistent, most creative and most publicized 9-year-old runaway in the history of the [[Pacific Northwest]]," while ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine included him in an article about "5 Amazing Runaway Kid Stories" alongside [[Harry Houdini]] and [[Benjamin Franklin]].<ref name="time">{{cite web |last1=Alter |first1=Charlotte |title=5 Amazing Runaway Kid Stories |url=http://time.com/70245/5-amazing-stories-of-runaway-kids/ |website=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=June 15, 2018 |date=April 21, 2014}}</ref> Booker was additionally featured on [[Dr. Phil (talk show)|Dr. Phil]] and [[Inside Edition]].<ref>http://www.exit133.com/articles/view/exclusive-transcript-from-dr-phil/</ref><ref>https://www.drphil.com/slideshows/runaways-gone-wild-semaj/</ref><ref>http://www.nbcnews.com/id/16795703/ns/us_news-life/t/mothers-proud--year-old-runaway-son/</ref>
Booker was later involved in another runaway attempt to Texas through the [[SeaTac/Airport station]].<ref>http://www.seattlepi.com/local/article/Boy-tries-to-hop-another-plane-1274613.php</ref> Additional actions put him in juvenile detention and eventually led to him and his siblings being placed a foster home.<ref>http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/11-year-old-who-once-hopped-plane-3-brothers-in-foster-care/</ref> Booker later escaped from his foster home, eventually returning to his mother's home. In his middle school years, during which he lived in Texas and North Carolina, Booker began playing organized [[basketball]].
== Basketball career == === High school === Throughout his high school tenure, he would go to four different campuses in Washington, at least one per each year of a regular high school tenure. In his sophomore season, he played for [[Lincoln High School (Tacoma, Washington)|Lincoln High School]] in [[Tacoma, Washington|Tacoma]].<ref>http://www.ncsasports.org/mens-basketball-recruiting/washington/tacoma/lincoln-high-school-tacoma/semaj-booker</ref> As a junior, he transferred to [[Curtis Senior High School]] in [[University Place, Washington]]. He also worked part-time as a referee at the time. He received a letter of interest from [[San Diego State University]] while at Curtis.<ref>https://lonzowire.usatoday.com/2018/04/10/this-jba-seattle-recruit-was-a-famous-runaway-stole-car-when-he-was-9/</ref> Before his 18th birthday at the end of his junior year, he wast involved with a serious fight that led to his suspension from school, and he attended summer school at [[Oakland Alternative High School]] in Tacoma. In his senior year, Booker transferred to [[Clover Park High School]] in Lakewood, Washington. He gained interest from both [[Tacoma Community College]] and [[Evergreen State College]], but Booker veered away from those places, eventually stopping himself from going to classes at Clover Park altogether at one point. He projected to go to a preparatory school in Illinois to finish high school properly, but couldn't in part because of the birth of his son, Mathayus King Blue-Booker, on December 22, 2016, and partially because of an arrest he had in February 2017, which would lead to a court case on July that year; the case relating to his latest arrest is currently unresolved.
=== Professional === Before making the move to play professionally, Booker played in a recreational league.<ref>http://www.latimes.com/sports/nba/la-sp-lavar-ball-jba-hernandez-20180621-story.html</ref> On April 7, 2018, Booker would be one of about 50 or 100 people to officially travel to [[Garfield High School (Washington)|Garfield High School]] to tryout for the [[Seattle Ballers]], one of eight teams created for the newly founded [[Junior Basketball Association]] (JBA).<ref>https://www.slamonline.com/uncategorized/jba-tryouts/</ref> After the tryouts for Seattle concluded, Booker was named one of four players (at the time) to be confirmed for the newly formed team. He would make his professional debut for the JBA on June 23 against the [[Dallas Ballers]] at the [[Health and Physical Education Arena|H&PE Arena]] in Houston, Texas. In that game, he recorded 12 points, 4 rebounds, 3 assists, a steal, and a block as a starter in a blowout 121–103 win over the [[Dallas Ballers]].<ref>http://www.fibalivestats.com/u/JBA/885626/bs.html</ref> In his next game a day later, he went on to become a bench player for Seattle in a 150–145 loss to the [[Los Angeles Ballers]], which featured premiere player [[LaMelo Ball]].<ref>http://www.fibalivestats.com/u/JBA/885629/bs.html</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.seattletimes.com/sports/high-school/semaj-booker-made-headlines-at-age-9-for-running-away-his-life-since-then-reveals-a-familiar-pattern-2/ Semaj Booker made national headlines at age 9 for running away. He hasn’t stopped running since.]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Booker, Semaj}} [[Category:1997 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:African-American people]] [[Category:African-American basketball players]] [[Category:American men's basketball players]] [[Category:Basketball players from Washington (state)]] [[Category:People from Lakewood, Washington]] [[Category:Junior Basketball Association players]] [[Category:Shooting guards]] [[Category:Small forwards]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Stephen Broden | image = Stephenbroden.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1952|04|11}} | birth_place = | nationality = American | other_names = | known_for = Candidate for U.S. Congress, Pundit, Professor, and Preacher | alma_mater = [[University of Michigan]] | occupation = Political Commentator and Pastor }}
'''Stephen Edward Broden''' (born April 11, 1952) is a former [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] political candidate from the state of [[Texas]] in the {{ushr|Texas|30|30th congressional district}} ([http://nationalatlas.gov/printable/images/preview/congdist/tx30_109.gif map]) for the [[United States House of Representatives]].<ref>[http://www.brodenforcongress.com/ Broden for Congress Official Site]</ref><ref>{{C-SPAN|Stephen Broden}}</ref> He was defeated by [[U.S. Democratic Party|Democratic]] incumbent [[Eddie Bernice Johnson]]. Broden is a businessman, political commentator, former professor, and an activist for [[pro-life]] causes.
==Education== Broden graduated from the [[University of Michigan]] with a Bachelor and then a Master of Arts degree in Communication, and he later studied at the [[Dallas Theological Seminary]] where he received a Master of Arts in Bible Studies.<ref name="Life and Liberty">{{cite web |title=Pastor Stephen Broden: Life and Liberty |url=http://lifeandliberty.org/about-life-and-liberty/pastor-browden |accessdate=September 11, 2010}}</ref>
He served as an Adjunct Professor at [[Dallas Baptist University]] from 1990 to 1992 and spent 10 years in the private sector at Atlantic Richfield Company ([[ARCO]]) in Human Resources. He has been a business owner of several self-serve car wash facilities, and has also worked as a newscaster, disc jockey, and radio broadcaster. Currently he is a co-host on the radio program ''Life and Liberty'' for KSKY, 660 AM and is also a radio broadcaster of One-Minute "thought of the day" commentaries on this station.<ref name="Life and Liberty" />
==Career== Broden founded the Fair Park Bible Fellowship Church in 1987 and serves as its Senior Pastor.<ref>[http://www.fpbfellowshipchurch.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4&Itemid=4 Note from the Pastor at Fair Park Bible Fellowship Church]</ref> He has served as President of the Fair Park Friendship Center for over 18 years and as its Executive Director for over 11 years.<ref>[http://www.pointofview.net/site/News2?page=NewsArticle&id=9225 Point of View Radio Talk Show]</ref> The center provides assistance to the community's "[[inner-city]]" families, including a clothing store and back-to-school rally where children from neighborhood families are provided with donated school supplies and family counseling.<ref>[http://www.crossroadsbible.org/STW/Outreach/communityoutreach/fairparkfc.htm Fair Park Friendship Center/After School Program]</ref>
Broden advocates in the [[Fair Park]] and [[South Dallas]] areas for economic opportunity, improved access to education, and against [[abortion]]. He is a spokesman for the black [[pro-life]] movement in Dallas and a contributor to blackprolifemovement.blogspot.com. He is a founder of Ebony [[Bereans|Berean]], an organization whose mission includes informing African-American Pastors of the "[[Culture War]]".<ref>[http://www.dallasyr.org/2010/02/congressional-district-30-candidate-forum-pastor-stephen-broden-sheldon-goldstein-and-charles-lingerfelt/ Dallas County Young Republicans Official Site]</ref>
He is a speaker for the [[Tea Party movement]]<ref>[http://www.kewego.com/video/iLyROoafMLPv.html Stephen Broden Inspired Tea Party Express Patriots]</ref><ref>[http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/city/rockwallrowlett/stories/DN-protests_12met.ART.State.Edition1.4c1f76b.html 9/12, Tea Party Groups Plan Rallies Throughout Dallas Area]</ref> and advocates for a return to what he considers proper [[U.S. Constitution|Constitutional]] principles in government and the [[Judeo-Christian]] values that he claims undergird the founding of the [[United States of America]].<ref>[http://www.thenewamerican.com/index.php/usnews/politics/4513-constitutionalist-pastor-stephen-brodens-political-star-rising Constitutionalist Pastor Stephen Broden's Political Star Rising]</ref> He supports an individual's right to bear arms, which he claims emanates from the [[Second Amendment to the United States Constitution|Second Amendment]], and a broad conception of the [[Tenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]].
Broden has been a recurring political commentator on [[Fox News Channel]], including appearances on the [[Glenn Beck]] show.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,596802,00.html Glenn Beck Issues Challenge to America's Pastors]</ref><ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,597082,00.html Glenn Beck: What Would Martin Luther King Think of America Today?]</ref>
He was awarded "Champion of the Republican Party" by the [[NRCC]] Business Advisory Council Texas and has also received the Ronald Reagan Gold Medal Award. From 1999 to 2002 he served as Republican Precinct Chairman in [[DeSoto, Texas]].<ref>[http://www.votesmart.org/bio.php?can_id=117504 Project Vote Smart]</ref>
==2010 election== On March 2, 2010, Broden won the [[Plurality (voting)|plurality]] of votes, in a three-way Republican [[primary election]] for the U.S. House in Texas's 30th congressional district, with 46.6%.<ref>[http://enr.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/mar02_148_state.htm Office of the Secretary of State 2010 Republican Party Primary Election Night Returns]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> On April 13, 2010 he won the Republican Primary [[runoff election]], with 67.5% of the votes, and became the 2010 Republican candidate for the November general election.<ref>[http://www.texastribune.org/texas-election-results/texas-2010-election-primary-runoff/ 2010 Primary Runoff Elections]</ref>
In October 2010 Broden was accused of saying that the current federal government was "tyrannical" and suggested [[Coup d'état|violent overthrow]] could not be ruled out if there was not a "change in leadership" resulting from the November elections during an interview with a local Dallas Television Station.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/news/texassouthwest/stories/DN-broden_22tex.ART0.State.Edition1.33278a9.html |title=Republican congressional candidate says violent overthrow of government is 'on the table' |first=Melanie |last=Mason |work=The Dallas Morning News |date=2010-10-22}}</ref>
Johnson ended up defeating Broden by a margin of over 54%. Johnson had the largest margin of victory of any Democrat running for the U.S. House in Texas in 2010.
==Anti-abortion== [[File:Stephen Broden (16405782316).jpg|thumb|Broden in 2015]] Broden argued<ref name="usatoday.com">{{cite news |title=Family cries as judge rules Munoz off life support |url=https://www.usatoday.com/videos/news/2014/01/25/4896973/ |accessdate=January 25, 2014 |newspaper=USA Today}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=HANKINS |first=LAMAR |title=Freethought San Marcos: Religion corrupts advance directives and medical care |url=http://smmercury.com/2014/01/15/freethought-san-marcos-religion-corrupts-advance-directives-and-medical-care/ |accessdate=January 25, 2014 |newspaper=San Marcos Mercury |date=January 15, 2014}}</ref> for continuation of artificial life support for the body of [[Marlise Munoz]] and led a vigil outside the Texas hospital where her body was kept on artificial life support.<ref>{{cite web |last=Sulenger |first=Cheryl |title=Pro-Life Rally Will Support "Dead" Mom Who Could Save Her Unborn Baby's Life |url=http://www.lifenews.com/2014/01/12/pro-life-rally-will-support-dead-mom-who-could-save-her-unborn-babys-life/ |publisher=LifeNews.com |accessdate=January 25, 2014}}</ref> She was 14 weeks pregnant when her husband found her unconscious in November, possibly from a blood clot and subsequently died from brain death.<ref>{{cite news |last=Dart |first=Tom |title=Texas hospital acknowledges brain-dead status of pregnant woman |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jan/24/texas-hospital-acknowledges-brain-dead-pregnant-woman |accessdate=January 25, 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=January 24, 2014}}</ref> Prior to her death she had indicated that she would not like to be kept artificially alive if brain dead.<ref>{{cite web |last=Luscombe |first=Belinda |title=Why the Dad Has No Say in Tragic Texas Brain Death Case |url=http://healthland.time.com/2014/01/10/why-the-dad-has-no-say-in-dismal-texas-brain-death-case/ |publisher=Time |accessdate=January 25, 2014}}</ref> The fetus had suffered from oxygen deprivation and was suspected to be non-viable. The fetus' lower extremities were deformed to the extent that the gender couldn't be determined. The unborn child also had fluid building up inside the skull ([[Hydrocephalus]]) and possibly had a heart problem.<ref>{{cite web |last=Bazelon |first=Emily |title=Brain-Dead Marlise Munoz's Fetus Is "Distinctly Abnormal." Please, Texas, Let This Nightmare End |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2014/01/23/marlise_munoz_case_the_fetus_of_a_brain_dead_texas_woman_is_said_to_be_distinctly.html |publisher=Slate.com |accessdate=January 25, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Brain-dead Tarrant woman's fetus is 'distinctly abnormal,' attorneys say |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/20140122-fetus-in-brain-dead-tarrant-woman-distinctly-abnormal-attorneys-say.ece |accessdate=January 25, 2014 |newspaper=The Associated Press/ The Dallas Morning News}}</ref> A 2002 study estimated the cost for an ICU bed in an average U.S. hospital is $2,000 to $3,000 per day.<ref>{{cite journal |last=JOHN M. LUCE, GORDON D. RUBENFELD |title=Can Health Care Costs Be Reduced by Limiting Intensive Care at the End of Life? |journal=American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine |year=2002 |volume=165 |issue=6 |pages=750–754 |doi=10.1164/ajrccm.165.6.2109045 |pmid=11897638 |url=http://www.atsjournals.org/doi/full/10.1164/ajrccm.165.6.2109045#.UtlFJmRDuYR |accessdate=January 25, 2014}}</ref> An attorney who had helped rewrite the Texas state law being used to keep her body on life support at [[John Peter Smith Hospital]] said that there was a problem with the application of the law to a patient that was no longer alive.<ref>{{cite news |last=Max B. Baker and Elizabeth Campbell |title=Texas law didn't anticipate Muñoz case, drafters say |url=http://www.star-telegram.com/2014/01/23/5509944/texas-law-didnt-anticipate-dead.html |accessdate=January 25, 2014 |newspaper=star telegram}}</ref> Her husband Erick, with the support of her family, successfully petitioned a court to order termination of life support.<ref name="usatoday.com"/>
==Personal life== Broden has lived in the [[Dallas, Texas]] area for more than 30 years and is married to Donna W. Broden. They have three children: Jamaal, 32, Maia, 30, and Stephenie, 25.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.brodenforcongress.com/ Official Site for Broden for Congress]
